body.p: Pollilt Studies in the Bible The printed Heb. To
To the Editor of the Occident

Rev Sir. I have for several years been anxious to see some
literary matter f grace the pages of your periodical
seeing however that your learned correspondents have
hitherto kept themselves aloof I (although not one of
the number) have resolved to send you from time
to time some random notes on the holy scriptures
more with a view to entice our Hebrew from their
hiding places then to gain popularity from anything
that might may issue from p my pen.

According to the authorized English version “Behold
the man is become as one of us to know good and evil.”
Mendelssohn translates it in the same manner. This
passage always appeared to me very difficult & obscure
The difficulty consists in the term Hebrew “one of us”
which plainly implies a divisible plurality. In consul=
ting the various commentators I find that Rashi quotes
the following remark from the Bereshith Rabbah
Hebrew
“Behold he is an only one below (or among the lower creation)
as well as I am an only one above, and in what consists

his unity? in knowing good and evil, which is not
the case with the brute creation” Although this remark
of Rashi may appear very simple in itself it yet (in
my humble opinion) contains the only true interpretation
of the text in question. But in order to arrive at the
proper meaning of the above quotations it is necessary
to notice two things. 1o According to Rashi's opinion
there is a great difference between Hebrew and Hebrew, in as
much as Hebrew means simply one where as the Hebrew signifies something
that is singled out or unique see for example, Gen XXVI 10
Hebrew “Well night one of the people Etc” Rashi there
remarks Hebrew “the peculiar one of the people this is
the thing”Gens 49.16 Hebrew “like one of the tribes of
Israel” Rashi there says Hebrew
Hebrew

“All Israel shall be as one with ? and he shall
Judge all of them and he prophecied this on Samson.
The term Hebrew may also be interpreted “like
the peculiar one of the tribes” this is David who issued
from Judah” In short where-ever we meet with the
word Hebrew I find that Rashi invariably interprets it
to mean something peculiar, singled out (or of
want of a better expression) unique 2o Some grammarians
all agree contend that the word Hebrew with a Dahgesh in the Hebrew is
the 3d pers mase Sing. and Hebrew without the Dahgesh is
the 1st pers plural The word Hebrew in our text
has the Dahgesh it mus can therefore not be the 1st
person. Taking these two points into consideration we

may come to a satisfactory solution by rendering
the text in question according to Rashi's views thus
“Behold man has become as an only one of his
own specie (namely in the material world) to know
good and evil (which is not the case with the
brute creation. The meaning of which is that since
his eating of the tree of knowledge he obtained ac=
quired that distinction. I verily believe that
Onkelos intended to convey the same idea in his
translation, he renders it Hebrew
It appears that Onkelos' translation has caused as
much difficulty as the tex original. Rabbi
Samuel David Luzzato in his work Hebrew Oheb Gare
finds fault with some editors where the disjunc=
tive accent (Hebrew) is placed on Hebrew, he says it
ought to be placed on Hebrew; he therefore understands
the ? thus “Behold man is now an only one
in this world, of himself he know to know good
and evil.” But if I were allowed to differ with
this most learned of modern critics I would
certainly read it Hebrew and translate it, “Behold
man has become an only one in this world of his”
(meaning the lower creation). Since writing the above
I found my opinions substantiated by two very res=
pectable witnesses namely Buxdorph's edition

wherein the disjunctive accent is on Hebrew and the Polyglott
bible where the accent is not only the accent is on
Hebrew but the words Hebrew are formed together
with a hyphen, and where they give the Latin
translation of Onkelos “Ecce Adā unicus est in
Seculo ex Se, Seiens bonn et malū., from which
it will be seen that Onkelos has generally been
understood as I stated. Now Mr Editor what I
here advance is merely a suggestion and if I am
wrong I shall be very happy to be convicted by
some of your learned correspondents. Should
this article prove palatable to some of your
readers I shall from time to time communi=
cate more of my reflections in the holy crip
tures hoping that our erudites men will rouse them
selves from their lethargy and give us all
the benefit of their secret meditations
